title: New York Search and Rescue Team Sets Out for Florida as Hurricane Dorian Approaches
text:
Hurricane Dorian was upgraded to a Category 4 storm on Friday, August 30, as teams across the US mobilized to support Florida and other areas expected to be impacted.

The National Hurricane Center (NHC), in an 8:30 pm ET update, described the hurricane as “extremely dangerous” with maximum sustained winds near 130 mph (215 km/h). Dorian was about 400 miles (645 km) east of the northwestern Bahamas and about 575 miles (925 km) east of West Palm Beach, Florida, at that time.

The hurricane was expected to move near or over the northwestern Bahamas on Sunday and near Florida late Monday, the NHC said. It also warned of a “prolonged period of live-threatening storm surge” and “devastating” winds for the northwestern Bahamas.

Early on August 30, New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the city would send personnel from the fire department, police and emergency management office to support efforts to prepare in Florida.

This video shows a team from the urban search and rescue team Task Force 1 setting out on their journey late that evening with equipment and materials. Credit: Commissioner Deanne Criswell via Storyful
